|071
Place a few actinulae in watch glasses with sea water, and
examine them two or three times a day. They will not develop much
further without feeding, which is difficult and will not be attempted
Sertularia.
The gonangium is large, oval and sessile, stouter in female
colonies than in males. It contains a blastostyle which does not
form free medusae but produces eggs or sperm more directly. The
eggs are fertilized in situ and gastrulate daru a secondary morular
delamination, forming planulae which have enough musculature for
movements. Embryos and planulae in various stages are often
found in apical swellings of the blastostyle called which
act as brood pouches.
In sertularia it has been reported that the primary polyp forms
from the side, shifting the organism's polarity 90 degrees. The
original planula becomes the hydrorhiza.
Eudendrium. (July, August)
The gonosomes of the two sexes are strikingly different. Those
of the female consist of loose irregular tufts of sporosacs (degenerw
ate, sessile medusa~forms or gonophores)mattached to the stem, each
sporosac being bright orange in color. ihe male sporosacs are light
pink and are found in groups of four or more which radiate off from
me nyarantn like spokes of a wheel. ine outermest, repeat male
sporosacs are white with spenn.
The eggs are fertilized within the female gonophore (sporosac)
and develop to the planula stage before being liberated. (Hargitt,C.
W. l904). Tease out embryos from different colonies and study all
stages found. The eggs are so rich in yolk that they cleave like
insect eggs. Gastrulation is by an extraordinary delamina~
tion. Metamorphosis is simple.
DEVELOEMENT GF 
Grease 01?   
Both these jellyfishes have oral lobes extending downward. In
mature specimens granular material will be found entangled on the
lobes. Tease off some of this material into a drop of sea water on
a slide, and examine under the microscope. Most of the particles
are masses of embryos, and must be further teased apart with needles.
Lt different points on the oral lobes embryos of different stages can
be found, from spherical cleaving eggs to oval gastrulating forms and
fully fermed stocky, active planulae. (Hargitt, G. T. (Hein
Is cleavage regular? ls gastrulation embolic or not?

watch glasses of sea water for further study en later days. Their
